issues.description: The problem statement UML (and the solution) specify a Stock.emptyStock() method, but the template Stock implementation provides a method named clearInventory() instead. This name mismatch is structural (method missing with expected signature/name) and will confuse students following the UML or cause compilation/test failures if tests or the reference solution expect emptyStock().
issues.suggested_fix: Make the template Stock class match the UML and solution by providing emptyStock() with the expected signature. Either rename clearInventory() to emptyStock(), or add a new emptyStock() method that delegates to clearInventory(), so the template, problem description, and solution are consistent.

issues.description: The problem statement (and solution) expect a Stock method named emptyStock(), but the template repository's Stock class provides a method named clearInventory() instead. This naming divergence for the same conceptual action (clearing/emptying the stock) can confuse students: they may look for emptyStock() as specified in the exercise and not find it in the starter code, or implement a new method duplicating functionality instead of using the provided one.
issues.suggested_fix: Rename the template method clearInventory() to emptyStock() (or add a delegating emptyStock() method that calls clearInventory()). This aligns the template with the problem statement and solution, removing the naming mismatch students must resolve.
